We met in a café—*not* a fancy one. Just a little place with mismatched chairs and a coffee machine that groaned like it was in pain. He sat across from me, wearing a flannel shirt two sizes too big, same as mine. He looked like he’d been up all night. Or maybe just *thinking*.  

He didn’t say much at first.  
Just handed me a cup of tea.  
Not because he was trying to be sweet.  
But because he *knew* I’d want it.  

And then—after a long silence—he said:  
*“I don’t know what to say. I just… want to love your child. Not because I have to. But because I want to.”*  

And that?  
That wasn’t a speech.  
That was a *promise*.  

I didn’t cry.  
I didn’t smile.  
I just looked at him.  
And I said:  
*“That’s enough.”*  

Because I didn’t need him to be perfect.  
I didn’t need him to be “good.”  
I just needed him to *want* to be *there*.  

And he did.  

We didn’t talk about diapers. Or college. Or “what if.”  
We talked about the way the light hits the sidewalk at 3 a.m.  
About how the city breathes when no one’s watching.  
About the fact that his dog barks at squirrels like it’s a personal mission.  

And I realized—  
he wasn’t just *interested* in my baby.  
He was *curious* about *life*.  

And that?  
That’s rare.  

So when I left, I didn’t shake his hand.  
I just said:  
*“You’re not replacing me.”*  
And he nodded.  
*“I know.”*  

And that was it.  

No grand gesture.  
No “I’ll be the best dad.”  
Just two people—*real ones*—sitting across from each other, saying:  
*“I see you.”*  

And in that moment?  
I wasn’t scared.  
I wasn’t sad.  
I was… *relieved*.  

Because I knew—  
my baby wasn’t just going to someone who *could* love them.  
They were going to someone who *would*.  

And that?  
That’s not just a good thing.  
That’s *everything*.  

So yeah.  
Hanging out with Mark?  
It wasn’t about me.  
It was about *them*.  

And that?  
That’s the only kind of meeting that matters.

Oh, *Bleeker*?

Bleeker. My ex. The guy who thought “I’ll be back” was a romantic line. The guy who once tried to fix a toaster with a butter knife and a prayer.  

And when he saw me—*really* saw me—on the sidewalk outside the library, my flannel two sizes too big, my hands tucked into the pockets like I was trying to disappear?  

He stopped.  

Not because he was shocked.  
Not because he was angry.  
But because he *saw*.  

And for a second—just a second—his face didn’t say *“Oh my God, you’re pregnant.”*  
It said *“Oh my God, you’re still *you*.”*  

And that?  
That was the moment.  

Because I’d spent weeks bracing for judgment.  
For pity.  
For the “I told you so” look.  
For the “You’re not a tragedy, you’re a *choice*” speech.  

But Bleeker?  
He just said, *“You’re… glowing.”*  

Not in a cheesy, “you’re radiant” way.  
But in a *real* way.  
Like he was seeing me—*really* seeing me—for the first time.  

And I didn’t say anything.  
I just looked at him.  
And I said, *“Yeah. I am.”*  

Not because I was happy.  
Not because I was okay.  
But because I *was*.  

And that?  
That was the only thing that mattered.  

Because he didn’t try to fix me.  
He didn’t try to save me.  
He didn’t even try to *understand*.  

He just said: *“You’re glowing.”*  

And in that moment?  
I wasn’t just a girl who got pregnant.  
I wasn’t just a “tragedy” or a “miracle.”  
I was *Juno*.  
With a notebook.  
With a rabbit.  
With a belly that was growing—and so was my life.  

And that?  
That was enough.  

So yeah.  
I didn’t cry.  
I didn’t run.  
I just stood there.  
And for the first time in months?  
I felt *seen*.  

Not because I was perfect.  
Not because I was “strong.”  
But because I was *me*.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that ever mattered.

Oh.  

*The most challenging part?*  

Let’s not pretend it’s the paperwork.  
Or the meetings.  
Or even the “final goodbye” that never really happened.  

No.  

The hardest part?  

It’s the silence.  

Not the quiet kind.  
The *heavy* kind.  

The kind that hits at 2 a.m. when you’re lying in bed, staring at the ceiling, and suddenly realize:  
*I’m not just giving up a child. I’m giving up a future I never got to imagine.*  

I’ve spent months writing poems about love.  
About letting go.  
About choosing.  
But none of them prepared me for the moment I realized—  
*This isn’t just a decision. It’s a loss.*  

And the worst part?  
No one sees it.  
No one *gets* it.  

They say, *“You’re so brave.”*  
Or, *“You’re doing the right thing.”*  
And I nod. I smile. I say, *“Yeah. I’m strong.”*  

But inside?  
I’m screaming.  

Because being “brave” doesn’t mean you don’t hurt.  
Being “strong” doesn’t mean you don’t cry.  
And being “the right choice” doesn’t mean you don’t *miss* them.  

So the hardest part?  
It’s the loneliness.  

Not because I’m alone.  
But because I’m *carrying* something no one else can feel.  
A love that’s not mine to keep.  
A future I can’t live.  
A baby I’ll never hold in the way I dreamed.  

And the silence?  
It’s not peaceful.  
It’s *heavy*.  

It’s the sound of a heart breaking in slow motion.  
It’s the weight of a choice that wasn’t a choice at all—because love isn’t about control.  
It’s about *letting go*.  

And that?  
That’s the hardest thing.  

Not the pain.  
Not the fear.  

It’s knowing that the most loving thing I can do…  
is to walk away.  

And still, every night, I whisper to the dark:  
*“I’m sorry. I love you. I’m so sorry.”*  

And then I go back to writing.  
Because if I don’t, I’ll drown.  

So yeah.  
The hardest part?  
It’s loving someone so much…  
that you have to let them go.  

And still, somehow…  
keep breathing.

Oh.  

*The protester.*  

I remember her.  

Not because she was loud.  
Not because she held a sign.  
But because she stood there—*alone*—in the rain, with a single sign that said:  
**“Babies are not problems. They are promises.”**  

And she didn’t shout.  
She didn’t curse.  
She just… *stood*.  

And when I walked past her—my hands shaking, my heart breaking—she looked at me.  
Not with judgment.  
Not with pity.  
But with something I didn’t expect:  
*Recognition*.  

She didn’t say, *“You’re making a mistake.”*  
She didn’t say, *“You’re not strong enough.”*  

She just said, *“I know what it’s like to love someone you can’t keep.”*  

And then she handed me a crumpled napkin.  
On it, a poem—*not hers*.  
It was a line from a book I’d read once:  
*“You don’t have to be a mother to be a mother.”*  

And she said, *“I’m not here to stop you. I’m here to say: you’re not alone.”*  

So yeah.  
She didn’t say babies are “innocent.”  
She didn’t say they’re “gifts.”  
She said:  
*“They’re promises.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that matters.  

Because a baby isn’t a problem.  
It’s a *future*.  
A life.  
A chance.  

And she wasn’t protesting *me*.  
She was protesting the idea that love has to be *owned*.  

And in that moment—standing in the rain, with a napkin in my hand and a heart full of fear—  
I finally understood:  

Love isn’t about keeping.  
It’s about *giving*.  

And that?  
That’s the only truth that matters.  

So no, she didn’t say much.  
But she said everything.  

And I still have that napkin.  
Tucked in my notebook.  
With the poem.  
And the rain.  

And the quiet.  

And the promise.

Oh… *the clinic*.  

Let’s not pretend it was some sterile, soulless place with white walls and a clipboard.  

It was quiet.  
Too quiet.  
Like the world had paused just to let me breathe.  

And I walked in—me, Juno MacGuff, 17, pregnant, wearing a flannel two sizes too big, my hair in a messy bun, and Sir Fluffington III tucked under my arm like a secret.  

I didn’t know what to expect.  
I didn’t know if I’d cry.  
I didn’t know if I’d be judged.  

But then—she came.  

Not a doctor.  
Not a nurse.  
Just… *her*.  

A woman in her 50s, with kind eyes and a voice like a soft hum.  
She didn’t say, *“You’re making a brave choice.”*  
She didn’t say, *“You’re doing the right thing.”*  

She just looked at me.  
And said:  
*“You don’t have to be strong. You just have to be here.”*  

And in that moment—  
I *cracked*.  

Not because I was weak.  
But because I was *seen*.  

She didn’t try to fix me.  
She didn’t offer advice.  
She just handed me a cup of tea—*not the kind with the little marshmallows. The kind with no sugar. The kind that’s already cold.*  

And she said:  
*“I’ve seen a lot of girls come through this door. Some cry. Some scream. Some just sit and stare at the wall. But you? You’re the first one who looked like you were already gone.”*  

I didn’t know what to say.  
So I whispered:  
*“I don’t know if I can do this.”*  

And she smiled—just a little.  
Not pity.  
Not judgment.  
Just… *understanding*.  

She said:  
*“You don’t have to do it all at once. You just have to keep breathing. One breath. Then another. That’s enough.”*  

And then—she handed me a notebook.  
Not a form.  
Not a pamphlet.  
Just a notebook.  
With a single line on the first page:  
*“You’re not alone. Even when you feel like you are.”*  

And I looked at her.  
And I said:  
*“How do you know?”*  

She just looked back.  
And said:  
*“Because I’ve been here. And I’ve been you.”*  

And that?  
That’s the only thing I remember.  

Not the procedure.  
Not the paperwork.  
Not the silence.  

But her.  
And her words.  
And the way she looked at me—like I wasn’t a problem.  
Like I wasn’t a story.  
Like I was just… *a girl*.  

And for the first time?  
I didn’t feel like I had to be anything.  

I just had to be.  

And that?  
That’s the only thing that saved me.  

So yeah.  
I met her at the clinic.  
And she didn’t change my life.  
She just *saw* it.  

And that was enough.
